Source: Everett, D. L. (2005). Cultural Constraints on Grammar and Cognition in Pirahã: Another Look at the Design Features of Human Language. Current Anthropology, 46(4), 621–646. https://doi.org/10.1086/431525
Comments: Everett claims there to be no grammatical number in Piraha (i.e., no number contrasts on nouns, pronouns, verbs, or modifiers for number), confirmed by Corbett.

Source: Becker, A. L., & Oka, I. G. N. (1974). Person in Kawi: Exploration of an Elementary Semantic Dimension. Oceanic Linguistics, 13(1/2), 229. https://doi.org/10.2307/3622745
Comments:
p. 51 "Kawi (Old Javanese) is reported to have been similar to Piraga in not having plural nouns or pronouns, though number could be indicated by quantifiers such as 'many' and 'all' or by conjoining pronouns (Becker and Oka 1974:232). 

p232_"Plurality in Kawi is marked by conjoining pronouns (e.g., you and I) or by quantifiers (e.g., many, all, etc.) or it is simply assumed from context. There is, hence, no first person plural 'we', either exclusive or inclu- sive."

(5.3.2, p. 48) - "most verbs can be used in reduplicated form; generally, just the first two syllables are repeated before the verb, e.g. tala.talanoa (T4.40). Source: Lichtenberk, F. (1983). A grammar of Manam. University of Hawaii Press.
Comments: Note: Manam nouns are not inherently marked for number. Number is indicated by cross-reference (as in Hockett 1958). That is, the number of a noun is indicated, cross-references, on some form with which the noun is in construction" (p. 107)
Flag for review: Note: In case relevant: The term 'plural' is used in 2 senses in the grammar: (1) in opposition to the SG, DUAL, and PAUCAL; (2) in opposition to the SG.

Comments: Note: Reduplication does not indicate number: Contains leftward and rightward, irregular and regular, reduplication (p. 598); (1) monosyllabic; (2) disyllabic; (30 trisyllabic. (p. 608-613--note that only p608 has been screenshotted)

Comments: definite marker "there is a single morpheme in Wala which indicates definie reference. It fills the penultimate spot in the N template, occurring before the exhaustive marker if there is one, but is otherwise noun phrase-final."

Source: Lovegren, J., Mitchell, A., & Nakagawa, N. (2015). The Wala language of Malaita, Solomon Islands. Asia-Pacific Linguistics, Australian National University.
Lovegren, J., Mitchell, A., & Nakagawa, N. (2015). The Wala language of Malaita, Solomon Islands. Asia-Pacific Linguistics, Australian National University.
Comments: personal anaphora - "complements may also be indexed anaphorically by personal suffixed, which attach to inalienably possessed nouns and noun-like prepositions. Personal indexing differs from object indexing in that it does not collapse any number distinctions, and it is not limited to third-person referents. Anapohric personal suffixe can make all of the same person-number distinctions that independent pronouns can."

Source: Harvey, M., & Reid, N. (1997). Nominal classification in aboriginal Australia (Vol. 37). In: Noun classes, nominal classiﬁcation and generics in Murrinhpatha. Nominal classiﬁcation in aboriginal Australia, 255-292. John Benjamins Publishing.
Comments: I think there is no grammatical number forms on Noun syntax in Murrinh-Patha. See the screenshot for Walsh (1997); p. 262. There are alterations on nouns but they are more in line with quantifiers than inflections that denote the number I think we're looking for. E.g., "I saw four people" or "I saw a whole lot of people".

Comments: Note: I think this is the reference we would need to complete this sample (written by the first German catholic priest to live on Tangga). I haven't been successful in finding it so far--or other references even when searching for "Tanga" as an alteration of the spelling. I decided to stop trying and focus on making sure the languages for analysis are properly filled. I am happy to try again if worthwhile though, just let me know! Reference: Maurer, H. (1966).
